From: "Mattias Fagerlund" <mattias@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Another New Paper:  Multiagent HyperNEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=29390171; y=mJDH8ygr-TwWtg8Zns7RXFaCZGswNUW91V-NT6cGYdOBqSbrWSyAezdgzsM
X-Yahoo-Profile: mattias_fagerlund

Hi,

It's my understanding that the r(x) method (call it method 1a) is used to
provide the genotype->phenotype conversion with the information required
to produce different phenotypes for different starting positions, in
effect, allowing the HyperNEAT framework to create different phenotypes
for different roles. This could alternatively have been done by inputing a
fifth posotion input node (making the five x1,y1,x2,y2 and Position, call
it method 1b), which would also have allowed the genotype->phenotype
conversion to implement different phenotypes for different roles. 

My suggestion was simpler still, to implement the same phenotype for each
position, but adding an input node (at the phenotype) specifying position
(call it method 2). This input could be used to inhibit or excite the
functioning of nodes within the phenotype, depending on position. This
would also allow roles to evolve, but using a different method.

For a comprehensive investigation, which might be well beyond the scope of
the research - the paper did demonstrate a very successfull test, I'd
personally like to see all three methods implemented. 1a and 1b are very
similar in reality and genotype->phenotype conversion has all the
information required to switch between 1a and 1b internally, though
supplying the information explicitly as per 1b _might_ be more powerful
for evolving. 

with regards,
mattias

-----Original Message-----
From: "afcarl2" <a.carl@...>
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Fri, 25 Apr 2008 16:26:47 -0000
Subject: [neat] Re: Another New Paper:  Multiagent HyperNEAT

> Just for the record, and for the benefit of the group, isn't the "r
> (x) method" just a mechanism employed within the current 
> infrastructure limitations, to map multiple agents within the 
> substraite and generalize the CPPN to the presence of the multiple 
> agents?
